conclusion: Analyze the acceleration-time graph to find when the object's velocity is at maximum.
The body starts from rest with initial velocity 0 m/s.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 3 seconds, acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0 m/s².
From t = 3 to t = 4 seconds, acceleration becomes negative, decreasing from 0 m/s² to -2 m/s².
Calculate change in velocity from t = 0 to t = 1 second: Δv = 2 m/s.
At t = 1 second, velocity v = 2 m/s.
Calculate average acceleration from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds: a_avg = 1 m/s².
Calculate change in velocity from t = 1 to t = 3 seconds: Δv = 2 m/s.
At t = 3 seconds, velocity v = 4 m/s.
Calculate average acceleration from t = 3 to t = 4 seconds: a_avg = -1 m/s².
Calculate change in velocity from t = 3 to t = 4 seconds: Δv = -1 m/s.
At t = 4 seconds, velocity v = 3 m/s.
Velocity increases from t = 0 to t = 3 seconds, then decreases.
The object's velocity is at its maximum at t = 3 seconds.
